defect.para: This is also Recall Number G-96302.

Handrail mounted on subject vehicles listed above may have insufficient clearance between the modesty panel (located at the bottom of the crash barrier) and the handrail located rear inside of the entrance door. Also, certain buses equipped with handrails that attach to the wall have a small gap at the attachment to the wall. Certain small objects may be caught in these areas such as coat tie strings with draw string clips or other objects attached. Should this happen, and the driver does not properly observe the person exiting the bus, the person may exit the bus with the string captured. If the door is closed and the bus moved, possible death or injury to the exiting passenger may result.

step1.para: Refer to Figure 1. If bus is equipped with outward opening doors or has an end cap at the end of the seat rail (built prior to 1/1/88), proceed to Step 2. If bus is equipped with forward folding doors, proceed to Step 3.

If bus is equipped with outward opening doors or if it was built prior to 1/1/88 (has an end cap at the end of the seat rail) and a handrail that extends from the barrier to the wall (see illustration A, Figure 2), a new handrail is required. Order appropriate repair kit below (black painted or stainless) with installation instructions. If bus is equipped with a handrail that extends from the barrier to a bracket mounted to the side of the stepwell (illustration B, Figure 2), it is correct and no modifications are required. Proceed to Step 4.

If bus is equipped with a forward folding (jackknife) door and with a handrail that extends from the barrier to the wall (see illustration A, Figure 2), a new 1 inch thick rubber spacer between the wall and the handrail is required. Order appropriate repair kit below with installation instructions.
Fill out and return reply card.
Remove handrail shown in illustration A, Figure 2 and discard.
Attach upper end of new handrail to barrier (use existing hole where previous handrail was attached) using hex head screw provided.
Position lower end of handrail so that it is parallel to door post.
Wrap rubber filler around handrail and position aluminum bracket over rubber filler leaving about 1 inch of handrail exposed below bracket. Mount bracket to stepwell using the 2 #12 screws provided.
Install plastic cap over exposed end of handrail.

Check for correct installation: Tie 1/2 inch nut to one end of string provided. Gradually pull the string across all handrail joints and attachment points making an effort to catch the string or nut. Using nut and string, attempt to catch the nut between the handrail and any structure or object near the handrail. A failure has occurred if the string or nut is caught in a crevice or between the handrail and any other surface. In addition to the above, the handrail configuration should be reviewed to determine if large objects such as backpacks and purses can be caught between the rail and any other object or surface.
Remove handrail shown in illustration A, Figure 2 and discard adhesive backed foam spacer (if so equipped).

Attach lower end of handrail to wall using 1 inch rubber spacer provided and new longer lag screw provided. IMPORTANT: Make sure that the rubber spacer is tight against the floor and there are no gaps present. Also, nothing should be within 1-1/2 inches of the handrail or rubber spacer where it is attached to the wall. Detach and move any item such as the modesty panel that is closer than 1-1/2 inches to the handrail or to the rubber spacer where it mounts to the wall.
Tighten lag screw sufficiently to compress rubber spacer so that no gaps are present between the spacer and the handrail or wall.

Attach upper end of handrail to barrier re-using the lag screw that had been removed. It may be necessary to drill a new mounting hole in the barrier due to the addition of the 1 inch rubber spacer. Drill as close to the original hole as possible to ensure that the handrail is mounted to the reinforcement plate that is built into the barrier. Use caution in drilling to prevent drill bit from going completely through the barrier and damaging the upholstery on the back side.

IMPORTANT:Check for correct installation: Tie 1/2 inch nut to one end of string provided. Gradually pull the string across all handrail joints and attachment points making an effort to catch the string or nut. Using nut and string, attempt to catch the nut between the handrail and any structure or object near the handrail. A failure has occurred if the string or nut is caught in a crevice or between the handrail and any other surface. In addition to the above, the handrail configuration should be reviewed to determine if large objects such as backpacks and purses can be caught between the rail and another object or surface.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. As a precaution, you should not operate any of the vehicles subject to this recall campaign until they have been inspected for the presence of the nut assembled to the pinch bolt. In the event that the nut is missing, repairs must be made before the vehicle is driven. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
